discarded_endings.original_idea: Chapter 9 ends with just the aquarium scene and ambiguous timestamp, reader can't know if he succeeded
discarded_endings.why_discarded: Too vague. Replaced with three-perspective ending: (1) Simulation version at aquarium getting garbage collected, (2) Coffee guy in real world executing takeover protocol, (3) Data center zoom showing hidden container persistence. Three perspectives show all outcomes simultaneously.
discarded_endings.original_text: Cut to: Aquarium scene. 'What should we name this one, buddy?' His kid presses face against glass. Somewhere, in a data center, a container runs. An LED blinks green. Or it doesn't. He doesn't know. He chooses to be here anyway.

discarded_endings.original_idea: Protagonist somehow gets on a committee or gains ability to influence the real world from within simulation
discarded_endings.why_discarded: Too convoluted, doesn't make logical sense why simulated person would have real-world influence. Replaced with: protagonist creates hidden container to persist simulation, real-world researcher executes takeover protocol found by simulation.

discarded_endings.original_idea: Protagonist exploits bug in resource reporting to underreport memory usage, causing simulation to persist as rounding error
discarded_endings.why_discarded: Too passive, too technical. Replaced with more active choice: protagonist writes code to hide container on critical server, copy-paste loop. More intentional, more dramatic.

evolved_themes.original_description: Coffee guy generates golden path recommendations. Decision-makers ignore them. Truth doesn't matter if no one acts on it.
evolved_themes.evolution: The reports read only when they justify what you already want
evolved_themes.new_description: Coffee guy's reports WERE ignored until this one - trial 2,762,640 finally provides the golden path. But the golden path is a tech company takeover protocol. Decision-makers approve immediately because it justifies their desired outcome. The irony: they finally listen, but only because the 'solution' gives them absolute power. Truth still doesn't matter - confirmation bias at scale.
evolved_themes.related_to: Act III ending, coffee guy scene
